openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Botswana is recognized as one of the world's fastest growing economies, with an average annual growth rate of about 5% over the past decade.
• During the first 30 years of independence, private sector employment in Botswana grew at an average rate of approximately 10% per annum.
• Following a period of stagnation at the turn of the 21st century, Botswana's economy experienced a robust recovery, with GDP growth surpassing the 6–7% targets.
• Botswana has been commended by the African Development Bank for maintaining one of the longest continuous economic booms globally.
• Since the late 1960s, Botswana's economic growth has been comparable to that of some of Asia's largest economies.
• The government of Botswana has consistently maintained budget surpluses and holds extensive foreign exchange reserves.
• The country's economic success is primarily based on diamond mining, prudent fiscal policies, and a cautious foreign policy.
• Diamond mining is the cornerstone of Botswana's economy, contributing approximately 50% of government revenue, mainly through a 50:50 joint venture with De Beers in the Debswana Diamond Company.
• As of 2020, Botswana was rated as the third least corrupt country in Africa according to the Corruption Perceptions Index by Transparency International.
• Botswana has the fourth highest gross national income (GNI) per capita in purchasing power parity (PPP) in Africa, which is also above the global average.
• Trade unions in Botswana represent a minority of workers; they are generally loosely organized "in-house" unions.
• The Botswana Federation of Trade Unions (BFTU) is increasingly consolidating its role as the sole national trade union center in the country.

• Despite its economic achievements, Botswana faces challenges due to overreliance on mining, a high HIV/AIDS prevalence rate (approximately one in every three adults is seropositive), and unemployment.
• Botswana is the first high-burden country to be certified by the World Health Organization (WHO) for achieving a significant milestone in eliminating mother-to-child transmission of HIV.
• The section discusses the economy of Botswana, including historical aspects, with a focus on key economic sectors, growth trends, and challenges.
• An image depicts a man on a donkey herding goats in a dry river bed, illustrating rural livelihoods and environmental conditions.
• Botswana's GDP per capita (current) is compared to neighboring countries, with the note that the world average GDP per capita is set at 100, highlighting Botswana's relative economic standing.
• Agriculture remains a vital livelihood for approximately 70% of Botswana’s rural population, yet it supplies only about 50% of the country's food needs as of 2016.
• The agricultural sector contributed merely 1.8% to Botswana’s GDP in 2016, indicating its limited role in the national economy.
• Subsistence farming and cattle raising are the predominant activities within the agricultural sector.
• The sector faces significant challenges due to erratic rainfall patterns and poor soil quality, which hinder productivity and sustainability.
• Diamond mining and tourism are identified as other crucial sectors contributing significantly to Botswana’s economy.
• Substantial mineral deposits, particularly diamonds, were discovered in the 1970s, leading to sector growth.
• The mining sector's contribution to GDP increased from 25% in 1980 to 38% in 1998, reflecting its expanding importance.
• Economic growth in Botswana slowed between 2005 and 2008 and turned negative in 2009 due to the global financial crisis known as the Great Recession.
• During 2009, Botswana's economy contracted by 5.2%, marking a significant downturn.
• The contraction was worsened by a major global downturn in the industrial sector, which shrank by 30%.
• Botswana’s economic downturn during this period was notably steeper compared to most other African nations, which continued to experience growth despite the global recession.
• Botswana is traversed by major trans-African transportation routes, including the Cairo-Cape Town Highway and the Trans-Kalahari Corridor, facilitating regional trade and connectivity.
• The country is a member of the Southern African Customs Union (SACU), which includes South Africa, Lesotho, Eswatini, and Namibia, promoting regional economic integration.
• According to the World Bank, in 2001, SACU had a weighted average common external tariff rate of 3.6%, reflecting the trade policy framework within the union at that time.

• The U.S. Department of Commerce reports that Botswana faces very few tariff or non-tariff barriers to trade, aside from licensing restrictions for certain business operations, which are reserved for Botswana-based companies.
• Botswana’s trade policy score remains unchanged based on the revised trade factor methodology, indicating a stable trade policy environment.
• The primary export commodity of Botswana is diamonds, which constitute the main driver of its foreign exchange earnings.
• As of 2024, Botswana ranks as the world's second-largest diamond exporter, underscoring its significant role in the global diamond industry.
• The heavy dependence on diamond exports makes Botswana’s economy highly sensitive to fluctuations in global demand for diamonds, which is crucial for economic stability.
• Diamond exports have provided Botswana with substantial foreign exchange reserves, supporting economic stability and development.
• The diamond industry has served as a foundation for industrial development within Botswana and has stimulated improvements in the country's infrastructure.
• Despite their economic importance, diamond mines in Botswana are criticized for not being sufficiently labor-intensive, resulting in inadequate employment opportunities for the local workforce.
• The insufficient employment generated by diamond mining has contributed to Botswana’s structurally high unemployment rate, highlighting a significant economic and social challenge.
• The mining sector in Botswana is primarily operated by two large companies: Debswana and Bamangwato Concessions, Ltd. (BCL).
• Debswana was established through a partnership between the Botswana government and South Africa's De Beers, with both entities holding equal shares in the company.
• BCL also involves substantial government equity participation, indicating significant state involvement in its operations.
• BCL experienced prolonged periods of unprofitability, leading to its placement in provisional liquidation in late 2016.
• Following the provisional liquidation, BCL was formally placed into final liquidation by the High Court in June 2017.
• The Jwaneng diamond mine is the second-largest diamond mine in the world as of current data.
• Since the early 1980s, Botswana has been one of the world's largest producers of gem diamonds.
• Since independence, Botswana has opened eight large diamond mines.
• De Beers prospectors discovered diamonds in northern Botswana in the early 1970s.
• The first diamond mine in Botswana began production at Orapa in 1972.
• A smaller diamond mine was established at Letlhakane following the Orapa mine.
• The Jwaneng mine, now the richest diamond mine globally, opened in 1982 after being discovered when termites seeking water brought grains of diamond to the surface.
• In 2022, Botswana produced a total of 24 million carats of diamonds from Debswana.
• As of 2023, Botswana is the highest producer of diamonds by value in the world.
• The Orapa mine underwent the Orapa 2000 Expansion, opened in 2000, which increased annual output from 6 million carats to 12 million carats, raising total production to 26 million carats.
• In 2003, Debswana opened the Damtshaa diamond mine approximately 220 kilometers (140 miles) west of Francistown.
• The Damtshaa mine was placed into care and maintenance in December 2015 due to weak global demand but was scheduled to reopen in January 2018.
• Australia's Kimberley Diamond Company opened a mine in Lerala in 2008, marking Botswana's fifth diamond mine and the first not operated by Debswana.
• Kimberley Diamond Company shut down the Lerala mine in May 2017, citing weak market conditions.
• Most of Botswana's electricity is imported from South Africa's Eskom.
• Debswana operates the Morupule Colliery to supply coal for electricity generation.
• Botswana exported $3.12 thousand worth of electricity from 2021 to 2022, exclusively to Zimbabwe.
• In early 2008, the Southern African region experienced significant power shortages due to reliance on South Africa's power capacity shared through the Southern African Power Pool.
• Botswana has plans to become a net power exporter to the regional pool by expanding the Morupule power station and encouraging private investment.
• CIC Energy, a Canadian greenfield company, planned a 4-gigawatt power station and coal mines in Mmamabula; it was acquired in 2012 by India's Jindal Steel and Power.

• Jindal Africa aims to operate three surface mines in Mmamabula's coalfields and develop a power plant, with the mine expected to support 600MW power stations and regional coal exports, employing over 2,000 people.
• Botswana produces soda ash through Botash, a joint venture between the government and South Africa's Chlor-Alkali Holdings (CAH) Group.
• Botash has operated in Sua Pan, northeastern Botswana, since April 1991.
• Tourism is an increasingly significant sector in Botswana's economy, accounting for approximately 13.1% of the country's GDP in 2019.
• As of February 2024, reports indicate that tourism's contribution to GDP has decreased to less than 10%.
• Botswana is home to the Okavango Delta, one of the world's unique and renowned ecosystems, which serves as a major natural attraction.

• The country offers prominent game viewing and birding opportunities in the Okavango Delta and in Chobe National Park, which is notable for housing one of the largest herds of free-ranging elephants globally.
• The Central Kalahari Game Reserve provides additional game viewing experiences and features some of the most remote and pristine wilderness areas in southern Africa.
• Numerous national parks and game reserves in Botswana attract tourists due to their abundant wildlife and wetlands, making them key tourist destinations.
• The primary safari destinations in Botswana are Moremi Game Reserve within the Okavango Delta and Chobe National Park.

• Botswana actively participates in community-based natural resource management projects aimed at involving local villagers in tourism activities; an example is the village of Khwai and its Khwai Development Trust.
• The country was the setting for the 1980 film _The Gods Must Be Crazy_, although most filming took place in South Africa.
• Botswana was featured in the seventh season of _The Amazing Race_, which increased its visibility as a tourist destination.
• Tourism in Botswana has been further stimulated by the popularity of Alexander McCall Smith’s detective novels set in the country and the American dramatization based on these works.
• More than half of Botswana's population resides in rural areas and relies primarily on subsistence farming of crops and livestock.
• Agriculture in Botswana accounts for a small fraction of the national food supply and contributed only 1.8% to the country's GDP as of 2017, according to the CIA World Factbook.
• As of 2024, estimates indicate that agriculture's contribution to Botswana's GDP remains below 2%.
• Historically, cattle raising was central to Botswana's social and economic life prior to independence.
• The Botswana Meat Commission (BMC) held a monopoly on beef production until it was ended in late 2023.
• The national cattle herd was approximately 2.5 million head in the mid-1990s.

• In 1995, the government ordered the slaughter of the entire herd in Botswana's north-west Ngamiland District to prevent the spread of "cattle lung disease," which reduced the herd by at least 200,000 cattle.
• In 2018, Botswana's agricultural production included:
• 102,000 tons of root and tubers
• 46,000 tons of vegetables
• 17,000 tons of sorghum
• 13,000 tons of maize
• 8,000 tons of cabbage
• 6,000 tons of onions
• 5,000 tons of tomatoes
• Production also included smaller quantities of other agricultural products.

• The manufacturing industries in Botswana encompass a diverse range of sectors, including food processing (primarily beef processing), diamond processing, textile and garment manufacturing, beverage production, jewelry making, metals and metal products, soap manufacturing, construction materials production, and glass manufacturing.
• Manufacturing in Botswana holds significant growth potential but currently contributes approximately 5% to the country's gross domestic product (GDP).
• Over time, there has been a noticeable decline in the contribution of the manufacturing sector to Botswana's national economy.

• The decline in manufacturing's economic role is primarily attributed to several factors, including a lack of skilled labor, failure to adopt and keep pace with the latest technological advancements, diminished competitiveness, and ineffective marketing techniques.
• The science sector in Botswana is experiencing growth, indicating increasing investment and development in scientific research and innovation.

• The number of scientific publications by Botswanan scientists catalogued in international databases rose from 133 in 2009 to 210 in 2014, demonstrating a significant upward trend in research output.
• In 2018, Botswana produced a total of 281 scientific and technical journal articles, reflecting ongoing scientific productivity.
• Botswana has one of the highest levels of scientific productivity within the Sub-Saharan Africa region, highlighting its relative prominence in scientific research on the continent.
• The country possesses a high-tech industry, which includes a number of information technology companies contributing to technological advancement and economic diversification.
• In 2022, Botswana’s high-tech exports were valued at approximately $38 million, indicating the country's engagement in the global high-tech market and export capacity.

sections.section_name: Private sector development and foreign investment
openai_summarised_points: • Botswana aims to diversify its economy away from mineral dependence, as earnings from minerals have plateaued.
• External investment in Botswana has grown inconsistently; in the early 1990s, American companies Owens Corning and H.J. Heinz invested significantly in local production facilities.
• In 1997, the St. Paul Group acquired Botswana Insurance, a leading short-term insurance provider in the country.
• The American Business Council (ABC), comprising over 30 member companies, was established in Botswana in 1995 to promote American business interests.
• Hyundai operated a car assembly plant in Botswana from 1994 until 2000.
• Botswana is developing tourist resorts, exemplified by the Kasane resort, to boost tourism sector growth.
• The country has shifted its economic structure, with minerals now accounting for 25% of GDP, down from nearly 50% in the early 1990s.
• The financial and services sectors have expanded rapidly in the 2000s, surpassing mining as the leading industries due to increased foreign investment and management.
• Botswana abolished foreign exchange controls in 1999, facilitating international trade and investment.
• The country maintains a low corporate tax rate of 15%, with no restrictions on foreign ownership; as of January 2024, the corporate tax rate is approximately 4%.

• The government considers private-sector participation essential for the success of the Tenth National Development Plan (2009–2016) and emphasizes research and development to foster entrepreneurship and private-sector growth.

• Botswana is exploring additional policies such as a new Foreign Direct Investment Strategy, Competition Policy, Privatisation Master Plan, and National Export Development Strategy to enhance competitiveness.

• The country possesses extensive coal deposits, potentially making it one of the most coal-rich nations globally, with plans for large coal mines, coal-fired power plants, and a coal-to-liquid plant utilizing the Fischer–Tropsch process to produce synthetic automotive fuel.
• Botswana's good governance record earned it the rank of Africa’s third least corrupt country in the 2020 Corruption Perceptions Index, outperforming many European and Asian nations.
• The World Economic Forum ranked Botswana as the third most economically competitive country in Africa in 2002; however, it is no longer a member of the WEF.

• In 2001, Botswana received "A" grade credit ratings from Moody’s and Standard & Poor’s, indicating the best credit risk in Africa and comparable or superior to many countries in Central Europe, East Asia, and Latin America.
• As of 2024, Botswana’s credit ratings have declined to BBB+ from S&P and A3 from Moody’s, reflecting some economic challenges.

• U.S. investment in Botswana remains modest but is growing; major corporations like Coca-Cola and H.J. Heinz operate through direct investments, while franchises such as Kentucky Fried Chicken are present.
• Despite challenges such as small market size, landlocked geography, and bureaucratic hurdles, Botswana is considered one of the most promising investment opportunities in the developing world.
• Botswana has deep economic ties with South Africa, being part of the Southern Africa Customs Union (SACU), established in 1910, which includes Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, and South Africa.

• Under SACU, South Africa has historically collected levies on customs, sales, and excise duties for all member countries, sharing proceeds based on each country's import share; the revenue-sharing formula and duty decision-making are controlled by South Africa.
• The SACU arrangement was renegotiated in 2001, resulting in a new, ratified structure and the establishment of a SACU Secretariat in Windhoek, Namibia.
• Following South Africa’s accession to the WTO, SACU duties are decreasing, increasing the competitiveness of outside products in Botswana.

• Botswana is negotiating a free trade agreement with the U.S. and is also engaged in negotiations with Mercosur and the European Union for free trade agreements as part of the Southern African Development Community (SADC).

• Gaborone hosts the headquarters of SADC, a 14-nation regional organization that succeeded the Southern African Development Coordination Conference (SADCC, established in 1980), which aimed to reduce regional dependence on apartheid-era South Africa.
• SADC admitted South Africa as a member in 1994 and promotes regional growth, development, and economic integration.

• The SADC Trade Protocol, launched on 1 September 2000, aims to eliminate all tariffs and non-tariff barriers among the 11 signatory countries by 2012, providing Botswana companies with free access to a larger regional market.

• Botswana successfully implemented the Action Programme on the Elimination of Child Labour during 2006–2007, and in 2008, it was delisted by Free the Children as a country with child-labor facilities.

• Botswana's financial sector is experiencing growth, with the country’s national stock market, the Botswana Stock Exchange (BSE), based in Gaborone, responsible for operating and regulating the equities and fixed interest securities market.

• The BSE was formally established in 1989 and remains central to Botswana’s financial system, particularly its capital market, serving as a platform for government, quasi-government, and private sector entities to raise debt and equity capital.

• The BSE has just under 40 companies listed, but hosts the most prominent companies operating in Botswana across various industries, including Banking and Financial Services, Wholesaling and Retailing, Tourism, and Information Technology.
• Botswana’s currency, the pula, is fully convertible and is valued against a basket of currencies, with a significant weighting toward the South African Rand.
• Profits and direct investments can be repatriated freely from Botswana, with no restrictions.
• The Botswana government eliminated all exchange controls in 1999, facilitating free movement of capital.
• The Central Bank devalued the pula by 7.5% in February 2004 to maintain export competitiveness amid the real appreciation of the currency.
• A further 12% devaluation occurred in 2005, and subsequently, Botswana adopted a "Crawling peg" exchange rate policy.
• The Non-Bank Financial Institutions Regulatory Authority (NBFIRA), established recently, is responsible for overseeing all non-banking financial services entities in Botswana.
• As of 2020, approximately 82% of Botswana’s population had access to formal or informal financial services.
• Mobile banking services have recently been introduced in Botswana.

• The government and Central Bank have taken significant steps to modernize the payment system infrastructure, including establishing a code-line clearing system for cheques and electronic funds, as well as implementing a Real Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) system with SWIFT connectivity.

• Gaborone hosts the headquarters of the Southern African Development Community (SADC), a 14-nation regional organization that succeeded the Southern African Development Coordination Conference (SADCC).
• SADC was formed to promote regional economic development and reduce dependence on apartheid-era South Africa, and it became inclusive of South Africa as a member in 1994.
• SADC aims to encourage growth, development, and economic integration across Southern Africa.

• The SADC Trade Protocol, launched on 1 September 2000, commits signatory countries to eliminate all tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade by 2012, potentially providing Botswana companies with free access to a larger regional market.
• The Regional Centre for Southern Africa (RCSA), which implements the U.S. Agency for International Development’s (USAID) Initiative for Southern Africa (ISA), is headquartered in Gaborone.
